bestBHT.bht: The act of Jesus taking bread and giving it to his disciples bears evident trace of the same words used on another occasion, specifically at Emmaus. Jesus acts as the host, providing them with food and fish, signifying his provision. Though it is not mentioned whether Jesus ate himself, his presence at this breakfast was a confirmation of his resurrection and a testament to his role as their faithful Friend. This meal symbolizes his spiritual nourishment for his people, offering them the sustenance he has prepared for them.

Henry Alford: The words taketh bread, and giveth them, bear evident trace of the same words used on another occasion
The words taketh bread, and giveth them, remind us of the similar occurrence at Emmaus
The words taketh bread, and giveth them, bear evident trace of the same words used on another occasion, and remind us of the similar occurrence at Emmaus
Albert Barnes: It is not said that Jesus himself ate with them, but he gave them food.
The design of this interview seems to have been to convince them that he had truly risen from the dead.
He remained with them, was with them at their meal, conversed with them, and thus convinced them that he was the same Friend who had died.
Marvin Vincent: Both have the article - the loaf, the fish - apparently pointing to the provision which Jesus himself had made.
Giveth them. Nothing is said of His partaking Himself.
Philip Schaff: We might have expected to read of the ‘fishes’ rather than the ‘fish,’ for the meal prepared must have included a portion of the ‘fishes’...
Yet such is the importance which the Evangelist attaches to the latter that he speaks of it alone...
...and makes no farther allusion to the rest.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus acts as host at this early breakfast, his last meal with these seven faithful followers.
Taketh the bread, and giveth them.
John Gill: Christ came and took his place as the master of the feast, and head of the family."
In a spiritual sense, he provides plentifully for his people; gives them to eat of the hidden manna, and tree of life, and leads to fountains of living waters."
He encourages them to eat and drink freely, what is of his own preparing, and at his own expense provided for them.

bhtAttempts.bht: The act of Jesus taking bread and giving it to his disciples in John 21:13 has significant connections to other occurrences in the Bible, such as the one in Emmaus. It is worth noting that while Jesus provided the bread and fish, there is no mention of him partaking in the meal himself. By acting as the host, Jesus reaffirmed his presence and continued relationship with his faithful followers. This interaction served as a confirmation of his resurrection, effectively convincing them of his true identity. Though the mention of the fish alone may seem peculiar, it underscores the importance the evangelist places on it. Ultimately, this meal symbolizes Christ's provision for his people, spiritually nourishing them with the hidden manna and living waters that he abundantly supplies.

The significance of Jesus taking bread and giving it to his disciples in this passage can be seen in its connection to the events in Emmaus. Jesus acted as the host, providing sustenance to his followers without partaking himself. This breakfast served as a confirmation of his resurrection, proving his identity to his faithful followers. The mention of the fish alone highlights its importance in the meal. Overall, this symbolic act emphasizes Christ's provision for his people, spiritually nourishing them with the hidden manna and living waters provided by him.

The act of Jesus taking bread and giving it to his disciples holds significance as it aligns with similar events, such as the one in Emmaus. By providing food without partaking himself, Jesus reaffirmed his presence and confirmed his resurrection. The emphasis on the fish alone points to its importance in the meal. This act symbolizes Christ's provision for his people, spiritually nourishing them with the hidden manna and living waters that he abundantly supplies.

The act of Jesus taking bread and giving it to his disciples bears evident trace of the same words used on another occasion, specifically at Emmaus. Jesus acts as the host, providing them with food and fish, signifying his provision. Though it is not mentioned whether Jesus ate himself, his presence at this breakfast was a confirmation of his resurrection and a testament to his role as their faithful Friend. This meal symbolizes his spiritual nourishment for his people, offering them the sustenance he has prepared for them.
